unfortunately we never held a key to the building, never had our own bank account, and had no formal organizational structure - we relied on good faith arrangements with others who fought & led with us, without ever thinking they could take it all away. lesson learned.
thanks, stef - that says it better than i could
we almost did it for this first ops but we couldn’t find anywhere we’d be able to park it. maybe after a successful year indoors somebody would let us use their parking lot
we just might

for a year we ran an ops in halifax, with a group of people that came together to support the health & rights of people who use drugs. we had positive feedback from the community & showed that it’s possible. i hope we changed some hearts & minds /13

eventually differences in philosophy & priority developed among our group and started a process that led to some people leaving & seems to have contributed to the site closing. this the part i still don’t understand, but hope to learn more soon 12/

but as the organization was focused on service delivery & trying to survive by a thread, we no longer seemed to prioritize advocacy, social justice, liberation, and centring voices at the margins we were really just trying to keep the site open against the odds 11/

i’m so glad that i could participate in the co-leadership of an organization along with advocates who use drugs & that centered the perspectives of people who use drugs our group also included lawyers, academics, health care professionals, and community service providers 10/
our leadership structure was amorphous & organic, even after the mi’kmaw native friendship centre graciously & generously took us on as a program, providing their insurance oversight in-kind 9/

our group leadership that had been focused on advocacy & policy change morphed into a focus on service delivery our priorities became establishing our operating procedures and continuing to connect with the few neighbours who expressed opposition to the site 8/

we operated on the t-shirt money. 3-4 hours per day, 6 days per week, employing people with lived experience of injection substance use as front line staff they did overdose response & cpr training, provided support and connection — they did outstanding work 7/

without any other viable options for a location, and with an increasingly toxic local drug supply & and the upcoming (last) federal election we felt we didn’t have much choice but to open the space where people who use drugs can use drugs & not have to die 6/

ns public health had been assisting us with our pitch to the provincial government & with planning for further community consultations, but suddenly the government told them they were no longer allowed to even reply to our emails 5/

through private donations, t-shirt sales, and a generous donation from  of both money and space, we opened the site last year there were a few community members who expressed vocal opposition to the site location, and this was challenging for us to navigate 4/

after years of planning, advocacy, and with largely very positive community support we were able to obtain an “urgent public health need site” exemption from health canada to operate our ops legally, but without any government political or financial support 3/
there are apparently other plans to establish an ops elsewhere in halifax some time soon, but  has so far not been invited to participate in that process 2/

heartbreaking that the ops we worked hard to establish is now closed we’re still trying to understand what happened & why, but members who had control over the physical space and to our financial resources decided that it could not continue in its current location 1/

20/ & yet in this new study case-control study to identify risk factors for ie, injecting controlled-release hydromorphone was not associated with increased risk. however, the difference might not be "statistically significant" because almost everyone in cases & controls used it

19/ this is the research team that identified sustained-release formulation of hydromorphone & sharing filters associated w/ increased risk of bacterial infection/ie (& hiv): https://www.thelancet.com/journals/laninf/article/piis1473-3099(19)30705-4/fulltext https://journals.plos.org/plosone/article?id=10.1371/journal.pone.0219777 https://journals.lww.com/jaids/fulltext/2019/08010/heating_injection_drug_preparation_equipment_used.20.aspx
18/ addendum 1: this really interesting study on risk factors for idu-ie by  & amazing team at western was published today
i'm not sure how valves might heal after a first episode, nor how long at elevated risk persists (maybe forever?)

clinically (& in some nova scotia data forthcoming) we've seen people with history of idu-ie who stop injecting and then have "unprovoked" ie months-years later & some w/ first episode ie years after stopping idu

that issue is recognized & medicalized to the point that the european infective endocarditis guidelines suggest considering empiric antifungal therapy for patients w/ ie who inject brown heroin "dissolved in lemon juice" https://academic.oup.com/eurheartj/article/36/44/3075/2293384

some interesting promixal-distal questions for the individual harm reduction practices too- eg. lemon water & vinegar as acidifiers increase risk of invasive fungal infection (due to contamination) vs. vit c http://www.bccdc.ca/resource-gallery/documents/educational%20materials/epid/other/vitamincqandajanuary2011.pdf but who doesn't have access to vit c & why?
thank you for you & your groups' work on this with ices data! learning so much from you

17/ in 2017  & i wrote this in  arguing addiction medicine & harm reduction have an obvious place on multidisciplinary "endocarditis teams" (guidelines say cardiologist/id/surgeon) leaders organizing ie care might consider:

some time soon i’m hoping to try to map a “risk environment” for invasive infections among pwid from qual & quant studies - i’m imagining risks for vertebral osteomyelitis, septic arthritis, etc might be similar

i’m thinking it’s a final common pathway to so many of these things gone wrong something not (yet) reflected in published literature is - i feel most patients i meet with ie are going through severe crisis; very rare to meet people who are in a good place when they get ie
16/ health care professionals caring for people with injection drug use-associated infective endocarditis in hospital might find this helpful, from a talk i gave last year:
thanks, josh! it's a small but mighty retrospective series. kim did an incredible job on really detailed chart review, and contributes to a need for way more data on the situation in atlantic canada

15/ overall, this paper adds to the growing knowledge that injection drug use-associated infective endocarditis is increasingly common, and deadly i hope soon we can help figure out the best ways to prevent it

14/ - stable housing - income - addiction treatment that fits, including injectable opioid agonist therapy - other harm reduction approaches, including easy access to safe injection sites & safe supply - decriminalization or legalization of drug use to take it out of alleyways

13/ while pwid can take some steps to help lower risk, in order to save lives i think we need bigger changes. i'm guessing we could reduce the rates of idu-associated ie if people who inject drugs had access to...

12/ other individual harm reduction interventions are promising, like the development of "wheel" filters and other types of filters to remove bacteria: https://harmreductionjournal.biomedcentral.com/articles/10.1186/s12954-016-0122-1

11/ sharing of filters and washes might be particularly dangerous for risk of serious infections like ie, since some bacteria can grow on old filters like a petri dish! this might be especially bad with controlled-release opioid formulations

10/ in terms of preventing ie in the first place, lessons learned from hiv & hep c prevention are helpful harm reduction & needle/syringe services & safe injection sites help teach to never share or re-use needles or syringes anything re-used can be contaminated w/ bacteria too

9/ unfortunately most hospitals don't have access to addiction medicine teams & most hospital-based doctors don't know how to prescribe methadone/buprenorphine ( ) https://academic.oup.com/ofid/article/6/7/ofz289/5520668 https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007/s11606-020-05815-0

8/ for people who inject drugs who develop ie, having an opportunity to see an addiction doctor while in hospital and start on methadone/buprenorphine reduces the changes of it happening again ( ) https://academic.oup.com/cid/article/68/11/1935/5142876

7/ our study also reinforced how horrible infective endocarditis is for people who inject drugs despite their young age, 1/2 of patients developed heart failure & nearly 1/2 needed valve replacement surgery 38% of patients died in the 2 years after their first episode of ie...

6/ overuse of acidifiers when preparing drugs may also play a role ( ) this can scar peripheral veins & lead people to use larger veins in neck & groin these are closer to heart valves & likely risk https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/s0955395915001036?via%3dihub

5/... - methamphetamine use, also associated with more frequent injection: https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/s1443950617303384?via%3dihub - & people more likely to be injecting multiple different substances:

4/ for example, shifting injection drug supplies to include: - fentanyl, which can require more frequent injection than heroin ( ): https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/s0955395919302786?via%3dihub - hydromorphcontin, which might not dissolve well: https://journals.plos.org/plosone/article?id=10.1371/journal.pone.0219777 https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/s1473309919307054?via%3dihub ...

3/ so why is the incidence of idu-associated ie increasing apparently everywhere? while this might be a world-wide phenomenon, theories reflect more localized changes in drug supply and preparation practices...

4/ australia https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/s1443950617303384?via%3dihub sweden https://journals.lww.com/md-journal/fulltext/2016/12060/low_mortality_but_increasing_incidence_of.87.aspx & probably more i'm not aware of...

3/ increasing rates of idu-associated ie over the past 5-10 years have been seen in many places: ontario () https://www.cmaj.ca/content/191/4/e93 usa ( ) https://academic.oup.com/ofid/article/3/3/ofw157/2593299 https://www.acpjournals.org/doi/full/10.7326/m18-2124?url_ver=z39.88-2003&rfr_id=ori:rid:crossref.org&rfr_dat=cr_pub%20%200pubmed uk ( ) https://wwwnc.cdc.gov/eid/article/23/8/17-0439_article & more

2/ we found that rates of injection drug use-associated infective endocarditis almost doubled from 2.28 per 100,000 population in 2013 to 4.00 per 100,000 in 2017 while we weren't able to investigate the reasons for this in this study...

1/ our new study including all cases of injection drug use-associated infective endocarditis in new brunswick, canada, 2013-2017, is now out in  open: https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/s2589790x20300615?via%3dihub led by med student kim mosseler w/   a summary/tweetorial

women face 1.5x risk vs. men contributing factors likely incl. gendered power dynamics- women are more likely to be injected by a partner, and be "second on the needle" (check out discussion of gendered risks for pwud in  paper):

more important work from   & co: people who inject heroin face 50x risk of hospital admission for severe bacterial infection vs. gen pop rates, and risk persists up to 10 years after first accessing opioid substitution treatment

23/ and thank you to the thoughtful  editors & anonymous reviewers who seriously improved the manuscript!

22/ sincere thanks to the patient for consenting to publish his case – when i asked permission, he told me: “you know i’ve seen plenty of rum fits in my time, and i don’t think that’s what i had!” i told him i agreed :)

21/ so check out our teachablemoment for a case & review with more references: https://jamanetwork.com/journals/jamainternalmedicine/fullarticle/2764289?guestaccesskey=9f9940b7-d6a4-4bbc-adcf-9fd0393999f6&utm_source=silverchair&utm_medium=email&utm_campaign=article_alert-jamainternalmedicine&utm_content=olf&utm_term=042720

20/ and alcohol anticraving meds prescribed at hospital discharge can help patients decrease or stop alcohol use, especially when outpatient clinicians will continue long-term prescribing & counseling: https://jamanetwork.com/journals/jamainternalmedicine/fullarticle/2659328 http://www.bumc.bu.edu/care/files/2014/04/jonas-et-al-2014.pdf

19/ finally, hospitalization provides great opportunities for helping patients with alcohol use disorder consider drinking less motivational interviewing or other brief interventions can happen on daily rounds and are effective for hospitalized patients https://www.cochranelibrary.com/cdsr/doi/10.1002/14651858.cd005191.pub3/full

18/ another twearl: patients who can report recent periods of abstinence with no seizures or delirium tremens, and have pawss <4, might not need benzos at all – consider gabapentin & close monitoring https://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/abs/10.1111/j.1530-0277.2009.00986.x

17/ there’s some limitations, as we discuss in our paper – pawss hasn’t been validated by an independent/external group, and it’s not clear if the definition of severe/“complicated” alcohol withdrawal in the original studies is reliable or patient-centred. but still promising!
16/ for people with alcohol withdrawal, pawss score 4 is reported to have 93% sensitivity & 99.5% specificity for predicting severe symptoms (requiring benzos) – and it’s available on

15/ the most promising method of predicting risk for severe alcohol withdrawal was pawss (prediction of alcohol withdrawal severity scale). this questionnaire is based on previous withdrawal symptoms and indicators of risky use and physical dependence:
14/ this question was asked in a recent appropriately-titled systematic review in :

13/ so if we’re suspecting a diagnosis of alcohol withdrawal, is there a way we could predict who is at high risk of severe withdrawal (and therefore might need benzodiazepines) vs. who is at low risk of severe withdrawal (and might avoid benzos altogether)?

12/ as a result, ciwa is overused in hospital settings, leading to unnecessary benzodiazepine use, sedation, falls, aspiration, and other harms: https://www.tandfonline.com/doi/full/10.1080/00952990.2017.1362418 check out our paper for the story of one patient in particular...

11/ this is partly because ciwa relies on patients’ specific answers to questions about symptoms. if they can’t meaningfully answer the questions (bc of delirium/dementia/language/sedation/intubation), ciwa can’t be used as it can’t even really be scored... another twearl!

10/ ciwa scale/protocols were developed for treating alcohol withdrawal in alcohol detox settings, not for patients in acute care hospitals with confounding symptoms and not for diagnosis of withdrawal. in fact, ciwa hasn’t been validated in acutely ill hospitalized patients!

9/ the major reason to treat alcohol withdrawal w/ benzos is to prevent withdrawal seizures & progression from mild symptoms to severe symptoms/dts. but not everyone who drinks heavily will experience withdrawal (let alone seizures/dts) & not everyone will need benzos or ciwa

8/ disorientation isn't typically a feature of mild-moderate alcohol withdrawal. if a patient is suddenly confused more than a few days after last drink (and hasn't progressed through more mild withdrawal symptoms), then keep a broad differential for delirium!

7/ one twearl is to know the typical timeline of alcohol withdrawal: symptoms tend to begin 6-12 hours after the last drink, and peak at 1-3 days. if dts are going to occur, they’re most likely to happen 3-7 days after last drink, after progressing through more mild symptoms

6/ & alcohol withdrawal can be tricky to diagnose in hospitalized patients with acute medical illness! is the patient anxious and sweaty because of pneumonia & sepsis? or are they confused because of delirium triggered by infection or medication? or is it alcohol withdrawal?

5/ alcohol withdrawal includes a wide spectrum of symptoms, from more mild ones like anxiety, shakes, and sweats, to more severe ones like seizures and “delirium tremens” or dts (a syndrome of disorientation, hallucinations, tachycardia, hypertension, and fevers)

4/ if a patient w/ heavy alcohol use is being admitted to hospital with acute illness, could we just start a ciwa protocol and then focus on the other medical stuff we’re more comfortable with? that’s what ciwa is for, right? maybe not! ;)

3/ and yet most internists & residents lack comfort with diagnosis & management of substance use disorders. traditionally, we’d rather focus on the alcohol-related cirrhosis or cardiomyopathy and leave the substance use to someone else! https://www.tandfonline.com/doi/abs/10.1080/08897077.2016.1187240?journalcode=wsub20

2/ heavy alcohol use and alcohol use disorders are extremely common in hospitalized patients. in canada, according to , there are more hospitalizations for causes 100% attributable to alcohol than for heart attacks! https://www.cihi.ca/sites/default/files/document/report-alcohol-hospitalizations-en-web.pdf

1/ new paper & tweetorial alert! how should we think about predicting, diagnosing, and treating alcohol withdrawal in sick hospitalized patients? based on our teachablemoments paper out today in  w/ :

in we have to memorize the jama rational clinical exam lrs for im board exam. the usual refrain is “look how useless the physical exam is” - and i want it to be “look how little / poor quality evidence we have for the physical exam, which is fundamentally helpful in practice!”
https://harmreduction.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/04/cov052_stimulantuseharmreduction-v01-3.pdf

but of course clinically we use combined dozens of data points to estimate post-test probabilities and structure differential so i use multiple lrs qualitatively (how informative is this symptom/sign/test) rather than quantitatively

my understanding is that since sn & sp for each separate test are calculated independently, lrs can’t be directly combined/multiplied since they’re often not independent (eg patients with bibasilar crackles more likely to have jvp elevation, so lrs are not independent)

to reduce publicly discarded needles, we need easy access to sharps disposal bins & should employ people with lived experience to help collect discarded needles.  peer navigator project is a shining example. https://twitter.com/needleexchange2/status/1116320570730340352?s=20 20/

this is also supported by existing research. people who attend scs and also inject in public explain that their public injecting is related to wait times at scs (and also to homelessness). 17/

a. people die when they use alone; b. there are many more injection drug users who could be using scs; c. when there's a wait, people may still use nearby scs/nearby caring people with naloxone. these seem like convincing arguments to increase capacity, not shut them down! 16/
after using at an scs, people go on about their day. after using in an alleyway, people go on about their day. after using in a mcdonald's bathroom, people go on about their day. 15/
i read this as saying that this human being would be dead if not for  14/

anonymous attendance at scs is enormously important in our society that stigmatizes & arrests people who use drugs and excludes them from traditional healthcare. identifying clients is not actually an operational issue. the authors' "distress" seems to be related to costing? 13/

scs/ops benefit fundamentally from the expertise, wisdom, thoughtfulness, creativity, passion, and connections of peer staff with lived experience. of course working in scs will not be for everyone. 12/

smoking is actually far safer than injecting in terms of risk of hiv, hep c, and bacterial infection. we  wish we could offer safe smoking area to support people transitioning to safer route of ingestion. 11/ https://www.catie.ca/en/practical-guides/hepc-in-depth/prevention-harm-reduction/safer-crack-smoking

even without formal drug checking, scs can reduce risk of overdose & infection by providing space & time to use carefully, try test dose to check potency https://www.tandfonline.com/doi/full/10.3109/16066359.2015.1068301?casa_token=oemvdnwo80oaaaaa%3axzbguts7hpazwgbffn129vti8qoc1cn9ni2wcxcrkvt6npibmarsawegfverexoz0xoakecndfyckg http://www.communityinsite.ca/stoltz07_injectingpractices_sif.pdf http://www.communityinsite.ca/kerr07_micro-environ_sif.pdf 10/

a huge benefit of scs is that they give people space and time to use without fear of arrest. using clean equipment in a clean space & connecting with community & health care support has health benefits for injecting all types of substances - not just opioids! 9/

misleading again. exemptions to section 56.1 of cdsa were not created in response to fentanyl. the supreme court declared that blocking scs violated the charter rights of people who use drugs, because it needlessly increased harm. history lesson here! https://www.communityinsite.ca/legal.html 8/

this one is terrifying. it's been known for decades that restricting needle distribution to 1-to-1 exchange leads to re-use of needles, increasing risks of hiv, hep c, and bacterial infections/endocarditis. this is a terrible, terrible idea. https://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/ottawa/1-for-1-needle-exchange-risky-costly-report-1.739887 7/

opioid overdose causes people to stop breathing and die from lack of oxygen. oxygen keeps people alive. naloxone reverses overdoses but can precipitate withdrawal, so often isn't needed if oxygen is available. don't need an md to know that oxygen keeps people alive. 6/

of course we do need improved access (with lower barriers) to evidence-based opioid addiction treatment incorporating medications (eg. methadone, suboxone) but scs offer something different- inclusion, connection & keeping people alive it's not either/or! 5/

in fact, our national treatment guidelines explicitly advise against detox alone as a treatment strategy. https://www.cmaj.ca/content/190/9/e247 very strange that detox is prioritized in this document co-authored by addiction physicians. 4/

the emphasis on "detox" as a reasonable alternative to scs (or referral to detox as a goal) is either disingenuous or ignortant. for opioid addiction, detox alone leads to loss of tolerance, relapse, and increased risk of death... 3/

a medical perspective shouldn't even be needed, as review mandate was supposed to focus only on identifying social/economic concerns. but the report is chock-full of misleading statements about the health benefits of scs, harm reduction, & addiction treatment- so here we go! 2/

& a really nice qualitative study publishing what many will know from experience, that washes of long-acting formulations can be saved for later or shared (and then think that the filters might be like little petri dishes)

this paper shows people with injection related endocarditis who are *prescribed* hm contin (and presumably inject it) are more likely to get endocarditis than people with injection-related endocarditis prescribed other opioids (including dilaudid):
this paper suggests it grows out in filters & can be killed with cooking (without decreasing opioid dose!):

really interesting program of research from  & colleagues (who aren't on twitter as far as i can tell) might be the long-acting formulation either (1)promotes bacterial growth itself, (2) more likely to stick in filters and be re-used or shared as washes, or (3) both
but increased bacterial infection risk with injecting hydromorph contin seems real, and has now become part of discussions/considerations when prescribing for people who might inject

hard to say at this point how much hydromorph contin contributes to idu-related endocarditis at population level, and whether hydromorph contin is more dangerous to inject than illicit fentanyl formulations (that could contain anything at all)

the endocarditis risk seems particularly increased with hydromorph contin (related to the long-acting formulation) rather than dilaudid. we do have lots of hydromorph contin here too (and its often preferred due to higher doses) so definitely concerns re: infection risk

i think widespread availability of hydromorphone in nova scotia has become *protective*. since our illicit/nonprescribed opioid supply has been hydromorphone rather than heroin, it hasn't been totally replaced with fentanyl (yet) and we've been shielded from many deaths.
here’s two of  papers on atypical overdose with rigidity: https://www.cmaj.ca/content/cmaj/190/17/e539.full.pdf

i’ve never given flumazenil bc we’re now trained to avoid it, but older docs tell me they’ve given flumazenil many times without seizure. i can imagine scenarios where it might be safer to give it (carefully dosed) than not give it. maybe could be studied in ops/scs in toronto?
